artist: Utagawa Hiroshige; Published by Nishimuraya Yohachi
creditline: Gift of Louis W. Hill, Jr.
marks: Ciisa ki wo/ saimaki to iu/ kurumaebi/ Shibaura ni Ichiryūsai Hiroshige ga 一立斎広重画
medium: Woodblock print (nishiki-e); ink and color on paper
text: Prawns and mackerel, harvested by the Japanese in late summer and early autumn, are typically garnished with sprigs of smartweed, a summer herb. A kyōka poem by Toshinoya no Tomiharu is inscribed at the upper right. When they are smaller prawns have a pattern on their shells that looks like the bands on a sheath. It helped the fishermen of Shibaura Beach band them together and catch them en masse.
title: Horse Mackerel, Freshwater Prawns, and Seaweed
